In 1954, major Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists and literary critics, backed by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, began to gather for a month-long celebration of the publication of the first Serbian and Croatian books in France. The occasion also contained an international conference on Slavic literature in France. During the conference there were many discussions on the ways in which the Serbian and Croatian literary traditions could serve as a bridge for the European literary project. The most significant among them was the conference held on 14-15th January 1959, in Paris between Srdja Trifunovic, the literary critic and leader of the Slovene Renaissance, and Jadranka Lajeva (later president-designate of the Council of Europe).

The Slovene Renaissance was a political movement and it took an active part in the formation of a new Slovenia. It was strongly in favour of the "cultural autonomy" of Slovenia, its independence from central authority.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two of which are "home" games (in other words, played in their home stadium) and two which are "away" games. The team in each of the four home "away" games plays the other team the next week and the teams play their "home" and "away" opponents the following week. Each team only plays four pre-season games, but there is a long-term schedule for each team in the preseason and postseason. Each team starts the preseason in the same week it goes onto the field for the regular season. For instance, the Philadelphia Eagles begin the first preseason game on Thursday, April 13, and finish the fourth preseason game on Sunday, April 20.

The 2016 NFL preseason schedule was released on November 27, 2016, and it will likely serve as a reminder of what the teams will be facing next year

original: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation is common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although there is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Camouflage is the most predominant mechanism for color variation, as it aids in the concealment of the organisms from predators or from their prey. Coat color can also be for intraspecies communication such as warning members of their species about predators, indicating health for reproductive purposes, communicating between mother and young, and intimidating predators. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation between populations and species is one of the primary means of differentiation among mammals.

Some mammals have a large number of hairs on one side of the face, such as the mouse. Such a hair appears on the face of one or both sides of the upper lip, under the chin, and is arranged in a ring around the eyes. The hairs are dark in color and are usually small. A few mammals such as the rhesus macaque, an important research model, have very few hair follicles on one side of the face, the eyebrows.

However, for most of recorded history, agriculture and foraging were inter-twined, in a way that still applies today, which is one of the main reasons why there have been significant and mutually beneficial relationships between modern humans and traditional (and sometimes even semi-modern) societies in general. A simple example of this is that of the domestication of plants, the introduction of cattle, and later the establishment of grain-based economies. In fact, early farmers and herders have been seen as the primary ancestors of our modern agricultural communities and in many cases have in fact become some of our most important predecessors in terms of cultural innovation and technological achievement.

By the 3rd millennium BC and the 4 th millennium BC , the populations living in these farming communities had significantly improved their agricultural practices , they were much better prepared to respond to climate change . Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it is a product of the human mind itself. It can then be contrasted with other kinds of knowledge: "What you know and don't know, what you want to know and what you don't, is a different affair; but whether you know or don't know is part of the same thing." A further distinction between the two domains is of course made by Popper (and not, as some might have it, between scientific knowledge of the present state of affairs and knowledge of the truth of propositions in general).

Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model in the rest of the British Empire.[26] There was no concept of 'the Crown'. In the British system of government the prime minister was held directly responsible and answerable to Parliament. There was no executive authority, no 'executive branch'. Ministers did not have the power to 'declare war', and no power to 'order' the British armed forces to execute orders of their ministers.[27]

All executive powers rested with the head of State and his minister.[citation needed]

In this system, powers were vested in the monarch, the government and the government ministers. In all instances, power was vested directly into the hands of the prime minister. The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea was divided into several smaller and younger landmasses, such as Laurasia, Gondwana and Neoproterozoic Canada. North America is considered a part of Laurasia and is part of the supercontinent Gondwana. In the Jurassic, one of three groups of landmasses was formed: Laurasia, Laurasia/Neoproterozoic Canada and Gondwana. original: Despite efforts to revive Hebrew as the national language of the Jewish people, knowledge of the language is not commonly possessed by Jews worldwide and English has emerged as the lingua franca of the Jewish diaspora. Although many Jews once had sufficient knowledge of Hebrew to study the classic literature, and Jewish languages like Yiddish and Ladino were commonly used as recently as the early 20th century, most Jews lack such knowledge today and English has by and large superseded most Jewish vernaculars. The three most commonly spoken languages among Jews today are Hebrew, English, and Russian. Some Romance languages, particularly French and Spanish, are also widely used. In most Jewish populations, these founder events probably represent, at best, a very small subset of all the Jews. This is somewhat less than the age of the first Jewish men from sub-Saharan Africa, so the evidence does not support the picture of a new migration from Africa to Europe and back. This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's cloaca. Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those of the other consoles and thus the NES was visually different from the other consoles, even when it was meant for one common machine. The reason for these design differences is that the NES had a dual core CPU from another company (see: Seiko 3) at the same time that other consoles were based on a single core CPU.

The Sega Master System and Mega Drive were made in Japan while the 16-bit consoles were made in America. However, due to the fact that this was not technically feasible the Master System was manufactured with just one core. The Mega Drive also had two cores per module, although for some unknown reasons there were three instead of four. These monetary units of the U.S. include the penny , the dime , the quarter , the half dollar , and the dollar as a whole . All of these monetary units share the same unit of value , regardless of the specific sizes of the coins in circulation . In order for these coins to fit their respective niches in circulation the design of each coin needed to be as durable as possible . By this the American coinage act wanted that all U .S . coins would be interchangeable across the continent . This act of interchangeable currencies and denominations was intended to keep the U.S. dollar as a unit of value stable in terms of the exchange value of all coins across the continent . A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, a true predator is one that actively kills prey even if they die naturally. The word predator comes from the Latin word "Progenitor", which means "one who has been created." A true predator is simply a carnivorous creature that has the ability to prey upon a certain kind of life form, such as a snake, lion, tiger, or tiger beetle. The word "true" refers to the fact that this is a creature that lives solely on feeding off other living things.

There are six possible types of true predators within the animal kingdom:

Ape

Ant

Beetle

Chameleon

Crane

Dragonfly

These creatures can all find food wherever they're able to live, and the types of food they eat may be completely different from what humans eat. For instance
completed: A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing . Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way , most prey species are safe from predators at least long enough to reproduce ( even if being able to breed is n't necessarily a sign a species is in danger ) . A true predator never harms its prey but kills it . The difference is in whether the animal acts against the purpose of the predator or not . In order to be a predator , the animals must be able to detect the presence of a potential predator . In order to kill and feed on another living thing , the predator must either see that the other animal poses a threat to itself or use hunting equipment to locate and kill an animal that could harm itself . Predators that act against their purpose do not kill any living thing . They simply kill a carcass or piece of an animal .

Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus or minus one, while PAL-specification discs could carry three analog audio tracks, plus or minus two.

Sound was stored in the sound device. Audio signals were transmitted directly to the sound device and then encoded into a standard bit stream, which could then be decoded at the sound device. The signal could be stored on a magnetic disk or recorded on to a phonograph disc.

Because of the way these machines stored sound, some sources such as a tape may be better than others. For example, a phonograph may sound better than vinyl on some types of recordings. Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to provide research, education and supervision to improve educational and child-rearing practices. Macfarlane was a pioneer of gender studies and a leading proponent of the feminist movement.

Over the decades, the Institute continued to evolve with Macfarlane's passing in 1976, and the Institute's faculty and affiliates became stronger. The Institute's most recent director, the feminist scholar Donna Haraway, received the 1993 American Psychological Association Award for distinguished service to psychology, as well as the 1993 American Psychological Association Women's Leadership Award.

Through its programs and fellowships, the Institute supports graduate students and undergraduate scholars in human development with opportunities for research, teaching and research training. The Institute also supports the graduate and professional schools, libraries and archives of the University of California, Berkeley.

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and complex. Memory is not static; it is continuously stored in our brain. The act of remembering, in the same way the act of making a record is, is an ongoing process of generating new, fresh memory and replaying it from one place to another in time-space so as to obtain a memory of something that occurred later. Memory, it should be emphasized, differs from ordinary memory, which is just remembering what you have been told, in the sense that'memory' refers to memories which represent actual events which occurred to the person at the time and which have not been forgotten by him, in the sense of being remembered only in part.

If each memory component operates on its own temporal window of activation , this would seem to represent different memory episodes . The answer is no – instead all memory components operate on the same time horizon , the temporal distribution of activation of the neurons comprising the memory circuit . original: The United States has become essentially a two-party system. Since a conservative (such as the Republican Party) and liberal (such as the Democratic Party) party has usually been the status quo within American politics. The first parties were called Federalist and Republican, followed by a brief period of Republican dominance before a split occurred between National Republicans and Democratic Republicans. The former became the Whig Party and the latter became the Democratic Party. The Whigs survived only for two decades before they split over the spread of slavery, those opposed becoming members of the new Republican Party, as did anti-slavery members of the Democratic Party. The United States has become essentially a two-party system. Since a conservative (such as the Republican Party) and liberal (such as the Democratic Party) view of the national interest has been so strong, and so deeply ingrained in the American public consciousness, that there is now no serious ideological opposition to its policies, this situation cannot be reversed for several more decades, although it may be altered in the next couple of years, by the actions of a liberal administration, or an extreme conservative administration. At present there is no serious opposition to President Obama, who has not displayed even the slightest inkling of the political courage to challenge the Democratic Party in a fundamental way. As things stand, the two-party system is not only dominant, but unchallengeable and unshakeable.

A Democratic president could change this situation by creating an independent media and promoting its objective, independent, objective discussion of political issues. This would prevent the two parties from creating a monopoly of power over the mass media
completed: The United States has become essentially a two-party system . Since a conservative ( such as the Republican Party ) and liberal ( such as the Democratic Party ) party can run in almost any state or even in two states or more , two -party registration in the U.S. is almost exclusively a product of national rather than local factors . This has been especially true in the U.S.A . since 1960 . The other feature of the two -party system in the U.S.A . is to prevent any possibility of a third party developing , while keeping the Democrats and Republicans in charge . The two parties are very similar , very conservative and very liberal . The main differences are in economics and foreign policy , and those differences usually coincide with geographic and religious differences . The American Two -Party System in Brief A two- party system is usually thought to arise due to the fact that there are only two major parties in a representative legislature ( the state or lower federal government ) .

A board-only organization is a special type of nonprofit organization the bylaws are made by the board rather than elected and is controlled by officers, often the organization's president. The officers are entitled to veto changes to the bylaws and to provide the board with nonvoting financial assistance. The board of directors can adopt bylaws that override and supersede the bylaws of the membership organization.

completed: The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only . A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws . For instance , in a membership organization , a board member could fire a fellow board member ( with cause ) . In contrast , the board - only nonprofit organization would still allow board members to fire each other , but it would be difficult to find a board member guilty of `` with cause `` because board members would have to show evidence of intent . For most purposes , the law is analogous , for instance , board members may be liable for wrongful acts during ordinary business of , but the same rules would generally apply . In a membership organization , a board member may be held personally liable , for instance , for wrongful acts

original: Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. The feast fell in late spring as spring gave way naturally to summer, and, with the changing temperatures, became the most important period in France's year. It represented the renewal of life and the beginning of winter. The festivities for the 12th of March included street and tavern markets, food courts, games, and theatrical performances. In the countryside, peasants threw large parties to celebrate.

People have been fascinated by claims that whites have evolved white skin through the process of selective breeding, while East Asians often have dark skin due to the fact that they had darker skin in their original homeland. original: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet

original: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is achieved by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase Breaks), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. Asian Americans in New York City, according to the 2010 Census, number more than one million, greater than the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles. The census numbers also give a sense of the diversity of the Chinese community in particular.

Over 20 percent identified as "multiculturized," in contrast to the general U.S. median of 19 percent. And more than 16 percent of those over 16 years old were born overseas, compared with 21 percent of the population as a whole and 10 percent among the foreign-born in the United States overall. Nearly two-thirds (65 percent) of the Chinese held master's or higher degrees, compared with 43 percent of the U.S. population. And only 4 percent of Chinese were homeless, compared with 5 percent of the homeless living in San Francisco.

completed: It is not clear exactly where collegiate a cappella began . The Rensselyrics of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute ( formerly known as the RPI Glee Club ) , established in 1873 , became official in 18 75 . This organization eventually absorbed the `` Chorus Society `` of Troy University , and the National Association of Amateur Musical Societies . The National Association of Colleges Amateurs , which began in 1924 in Boston , eventually grew to approximately one thousand collegiate a ca ppella organizations . Most other notable collegiate a ca ppella organizations are located in the United States . The United States Collegiate A cappella Federation ( USCAF ) is the official national association for collegiate a cappella . It is sponsored by the National Association of Colleg iate a cappella Societies ( NAC AS ) , the National Association of College and University P lyfying ( N AC UPC ) and the American Society of Compos ers , Authors and Publishers ( ASCAP ) . Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so.

The best sources of fatty acids are animal fat and high-fat plant foods like coconut oil and flax seeds.

Fatty acids have special structures, known as fatty acid chains, in their chemical structures that can be attached to molecules of fat or other substances, such as sugars, protein, and vitamins. Thus, the essential fatty acid is actually a chain of non-essential fatty acids, made up of chains of alternating fatty acid chains.

Essential fatty acids are considered to be nutrients essential to a healthy body and mind, whereas non-essential fatty acids can be included in any of the normal food groups in a diet. Many Londoners, living in unassuming tenements with little protection, sought their own escape routes. Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. Truman, himself a combat veteran of World War I, issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the Armed Forces Radio Broadcast Service in June 1942.

Truman's order required all military members to establish and maintain radio stations, to receive regular transmissions from Army units operating in various theaters of operation, to transmit such transmissions, and, of course, to transmit them, not only as a military broadcast but also for their general dissemination through civilian stations and wire services. By issuing his orders, Truman committed the U.S. Army to the radio project.

Despite the war efforts, the radio broadcast service proved to be less efficient than the wire service. This was due to a number of factors, including Army officials' insistence that Army units be authorized to transmit over the radio, without having to first obtain approval from the State Governors. The service also faced logistical difficulties--radio transmission equipment was of poor quality and many stations experienced technical difficulties.

original: Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to develop social skills such as empathy, sharing, and leadership. Adolescents choose peer groups based on characteristics similarly found in themselves. By utilizing these relationships, adolescents become more accepting of who they are becoming. Group norms and values are incorporated into an adolescent’s own self-concept. Through developing new communication skills and reflecting upon those of their peers, as well as self-opinions and values, an adolescent can share and express emotions and other concerns without fear of rejection or judgment. Peer groups can have positive influences on an individual, such as on academic motivation and performance. However, while peers may facilitate social development for one another they may also hinder it. Peers can have negative influences, such as encouraging experimentation with drugs, drinking, vandalism, and stealing through peer pressure. Susceptibility to peer pressure increases during early adolescence, peaks around age 14, and declines thereafter. Further evidence of peers hindering social development has been found in Spanish

Peer groups offer members the opportunity to identify with others and develop relationships with peer groups of like-minded people. Peer groups, then, can reinforce the peer group system in which individuals learn more and more skills from their peers through interactions at these social contacts, and as more they come to possess more skills, they progress through the peer group system to increasingly higher social status and influence within the peer group system. If the social skills of the group are weak, the group will not develop enough power to move them into leadership positions within the group.

completed: Ideas for affirmative action came as early as the Reconstruction Era ( 1865-1877 ) in which a former slave population lacked the skills and resources for sustainable living . In the southern states of the US , the new generation of white southerners that included some returning plan ters and their families that included more than a few freed slaves sought to change history by using race , class and gender-specific quotas to achieve some level of equality amongst all peoples in order to make the new republic a more attractive destination for newcomers and investors . In the long term the system became so successful ( with various levels of success still present in some states as recently as the 21st century ) that it became a global model used to increase the quality of educational opportunities for disadvantaged groups . However in the short term the quotas were resented by those in power and they were used against both black southerners and other minorities as a way of keeping black communities out .

original: Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage, or—in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology—"basic" plumage; breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey-Parkes system as "alternate" plumages. Moulting is annual in most species, although some may have two moults a year, and large birds of prey may moult only once every few years. Moulting patterns vary across species. In passerines, flight feathers are replaced one at a time with the innermost primary being the first. When the fifth of sixth primary is replaced, the outermost tertiaries begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the secondaries starting from the innermost begin to drop and this proceeds to the outer feathers (centrifugal moult). The greater primary coverts are moulted in synchrony with the primary that they overlap.

original: The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements about actual and possible sense data. But it came to be realized that there is no finite set of statements about actual and possible sense-data from which we can deduce even a single physical-object statement. Remember that the translating or paraphrasing statement must be couched in terms of normal observers in normal conditions of observation. The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical reality had very different implications from statements about mental objects. Physical states are no longer simply mental objects on which to pin our attention, but are rather something much deeper to be looked at in terms of what it means for a set of statements to be true or false. For instance, statements about the motion of a ship cannot be regarded as true or false because motion does not occur at all in the mind and no laws or relationships exist to connect a thought about motion with the actual motion of the ship itself.

Despite the growing appreciation of the fundamental difference between physical and mental states of affairs, the phenomenalist, despite being generally a naturalist, felt a sort of hesitance to drop his metaphysics in response to physicalism. But the post-Humean world seems to be so radically different from the mentalist world (where mental states

original: Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be prey for cats and snakes, and snakes may be the prey of hawks. One way of classifying predators is by trophic level. Organisms that feed on autotrophs, the producers of the trophic pyramid, are known as herbivores or primary consumers; those that feed on heterotrophs such as animals are known as secondary consumers. Secondary consumers are a type of carnivore, but there are also tertiary consumers eating these carnivores, quartary consumers eating them, and so forth. Because only a fraction of energy is passed on to the next level, this hierarchy of predation must end somewhere, and very seldom goes higher than five or six levels, and may go only as high as three trophic levels (for example, a lion that preys upon large herbivores such as wildebeest, which in turn eat grasses). original: The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. After the Warehouse closed in 1983, the crowds went to Knuckles' new club, The Power Plant. In the Channel 4 documentary Pump Up The Volume, Knuckles remarks that the first time he heard the term "house music" was upon seeing "we play house music" on a sign in the window of a bar on Chicago's South Side. One of the people in the car with him joked, "you know, that's the kind of music you play down at the Warehouse!", and then everybody laughed. The first commercial successes were made with the 1990 release of an album by The Neptunes called "The Boy Is Mine," which went multi-platinum and produced a major hit with "Da Funk." original: As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. There were fewer invasions of the eastern section of the empire; most occurred in the Balkans. Peace with Persia, the traditional enemy of Rome, lasted throughout most of the 5th century. The Eastern Empire was marked by closer relations between the political state and Christian Church, with doctrinal matters assuming an importance in eastern politics that they did not have in Western Europe. Legal developments included the codification of Roman law; the first effort—the Theodosian Code—was completed in 438. Under Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565), another compilation took place—the Corpus Juris Civilis. Justinian also oversaw the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths, under Belisarius (d. 565). original: Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. They were closely modeled after the mosaics of the Roman country villas, once common in the Eastern Mediterranean. The most superb example can be found in the bath house of Hisham's Palace, Palestine which was made around 744. The main panel depicts a large tree and underneath it a lion attacking a deer (right side) and two deers peacefully grazing (left side). The panel probably represents good and bad governance. Mosaics with classical geometric motifs survived in the bath area of the 8th-century Umayyad palace complex in Anjar, Lebanon. The luxurious desert residence of Al-Walid II in Qasr al-Hallabat (in present-day Jordan) was also decorated with floor mosaics that show a high level of technical skill. Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. Although the Islamic religious landscape became far removed from its pagan foundations following the Abbasid Revolution of the early 13th century, the Islamic pattern for architecture was still in place.


The main Islamic design was the so-called qanati, that is, an array of rectilinear, straight-faced pillars that stood above the floor. This was followed by the tiling of the roof which began with rectilinear pillars and arches. After these initial features were covered by a mosaic, the ceiling would be covered by mosaics with floral and geometric motifs. On the roof and ceiling, a pattern of black and white tiles known as kafan was very common. On the floors, carpet decoration was highly prized and covered many of the rooms. original: By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike first and turned his army's sights from the English Channel to the Rhine. His basic objective was to destroy the isolated Austrian armies in Southern Germany before their Russian allies could arrive. On 25 September, after great secrecy and feverish marching, 200,000 French troops began to cross the Rhine on a front of 260 km (160 mi). Austrian commander Karl Mack had gathered the greater part of the Austrian army at the fortress of Ulm in Swabia. Napoleon swung his forces to the southeast and the Grande Armée performed an elaborate wheeling movement that outflanked the Austrian positions. The Ulm Maneuver completely surprised General Mack, who belatedly understood that his army had been cut off. After some minor engagements that culminated in the Battle of Ulm, Mack finally surrendered after realizing that there was no way to break out of the French encirclement. This UN plan specified borders for the new State of Israel with its capital in Tel Aviv, its population in Israel excluding the Arab minority, and the rights and obligations of the displaced Palestinian groups.

The Partition Plan was submitted by an international commission, headed by the United Kingdom and Sweden. The commission, which met as the United Nations Economic and Social Council on 14 and 16 December 1947, met a few months before the UN vote on the Partition Plan.

In a climate of global warming at 1 degree above the preindustrial level, the City of Melbourne plans to reduce emissions by 70 per cent to 55 per cent of 2000 levels by 2050.

This will require substantial cuts in greenhouse gas emissions from the electricity and gas industries combined with an extensive program of large-scale renewable energy generation. The City estimates it must eliminate 6300 MW in electricity generation by 2020 and almost 2200 MW by 2050 to meet these targets. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian is official in the Valencian Country, as well as in Catalonia and the Balearic Islands, where it receives the name of Catalan. Despite the differentiated denomination, the distinct dialectal traits and political tension between Catalonia and the Valencian Country, Catalan and Valencian are mutually intelligible and are considered two varieties of the same language. Valencian has been historically repressed in favour of Spanish. The effects have been more noticeable in the city proper, whereas the language has remained active in the rural and metropolitan areas. After the Castille-Aragon unification, a Spanish-speaking elite established itself in the city. original: Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and estimates of its discovery place it at 9000 BC in the Middle East; a copper pendant was found in northern Iraq that dates to 8700 BC. There is evidence that gold and meteoric iron (but not iron smelting) were the only metals used by humans before copper. The history of copper metallurgy is thought to have followed the following sequence: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax method. In southeastern Anatolia, all four of these metallurgical techniques appears more or less simultaneously at the beginning of the Neolithic c. 7500 BC. However, just as agriculture was independently invented in several parts of the world, copper smelting was invented locally in several different places. A high heat transfer coefficient allowed more heat to be carried away in one direction, making the metal the ideal choice for weapons.

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the huge advances made throughout the century, the technology remained somewhat inefficient. The phonautographer was expensive, prone to malfunction and would require manual adjustments due to the poor quality of microphones and speaker combinations.

In 1927, J. P. Morgan and J. W. Carnegie had the idea to combine Edison's invention with other new technologies to create the first commercial computer. To create a sound recording of the same length as a human voice, a two-inch tape was mounted with a microphone to record audio with the voice. Using a reel-to-reel player, players would play a record using an electromagnet, which would rotate the tape along with the needle, resulting in recording sound. At this level of performance, the record could be sent across the radio frequency transmission spectrum by radio receivers, effectively creating a computer.

original: In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and reproduction; it is involved in the regulation and elimination of toxins; it is responsible for the production and destruction of cell structures, including the cell nucleus [9]. Energy is a major determinant (pigment and enzyme, especially) of physical, chemical and biological processes. It represents the sum of all work done within the cell. Energy does not exist in empty space, as energy is required in the development of any biological substance [10]. It is the sum of all work performed within the cell.

The cellular organization of human beings involves the use of energy, because this organization requires the efficient and precise allocation of energy by the cell. original: Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. original: The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. Their kingdom was a prosperous and prosperous one, with large grain and livestock farms and other productive assets, but they were also well-armed and they were a technologically minded, militarized state. Though they never managed to capture the capital, Lahore, or win a war of independence, they were militarily and economically capable enough to be in the same league as the Mughals. This is something the British weren't able to ever achieve in India to the extent that Mughal rule was and to the extent that the British sought independence in the country. Therefore they found it most appropriate to rule over a relatively weak and declining state – they had other things to worry about.

original: Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the island is covered in basaltic volcanoes). The island lies in some of the most extreme weather regimes on Earth. For example, the island experiences average winter temperature of -58.2° Celsius, which is 0.5° Celsius warmer than the global average of -40.9° and -42.1° Celsius respectively.


In terms of surface area it is smaller than that of the continental United States. On average, over the last 25 years around 6,100 residents have emigrated each year from the island.

Geographically, the island of Saint Helena is characterized by thick volcanic tectonic plate boundaries. The volcanic surface is composed mainly of basaltic lava. This lava was formed on and after the last major volcanic eruption within the last 5000 years. There are also several large volcanic craters. These features

In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12 hours of footage each night. This was called the "Midnight Special."

In a way, it's the classic recording for its time. Though Gabler uses a more technical approach than many sound men of the time, he still makes interesting use of the microphones and his own vocal stylings to create a story and, most importantly, capture the essence of the events taking place. There is a great deal of tension and mystery built into each recording. Here, he is in a small cottage; a very dangerous place to be at night. One minute he's out front; the next, up inside his own home. There's lots of very tense moments of negotiation, some shouting and much shouting. Most memorable is a shot of a woman screaming; an event that is of great importance to the characters in Gabler's stories.
